node.title: New suspected Omicron cases emerge across Europe as the world races to contain new variant
node.description: The world is on high alert as Germany and the Czech Republic find suspected cases of the new variant, and dozens of travellers from South Africa test positive for COVID-19 in the Netherlands.

node.title: Brazil’s President Lula Is Staging a Comeback. Can He Bring the Country Along?
node.description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former president, has beat back a flurry of corruption cases and climbed to the front of next year’s presidential race.

node.title: Asian nations expand booster shots, with an eye on Europe’s surge.
node.description: Some highly vaccinated countries in East and Southeast Asia are embracing boosters as the virus surges through parts of Europe where third shots are not yet widely available.

node.title: How Many Days a Week Do I Need to Workout to Notice a Difference?
node.description: A minimal amount of physical activity in a week will produce some health benefits. But how much exercise until we start seeing significant results? And what about diet?

node.title: The Netherlands finds 61 Covid cases in air arrivals from South Africa, and is checking for the variant.
node.description: The passengers were in the air when the Netherlands announced travel restrictions on flights from southern Africa.

node.title: 12 Outstanding Gifts for Your Significant Other That Will Make Your Love Grow
node.description: From gift ideas for that special person to gifts that couples can share together, these are all things that may benefit your relationship.

node.title: States and territories tighten border rules amid Omicron variant fears
node.description: New South Wales and Victoria reimpose quarantine requirements for international arrivals as South Australia and Western Australia tighten their border rules.

node.title: They Died From Covid. Then the Online Attacks Started.
node.description: The social media profiles of anti-vaccine victims of the pandemic have made them and their families targets of trolling, even after their deaths.

node.title: Growing Old in High Style
node.description: A new crop of luxury senior housing is turning retirement into a five-star resort stay.

node.title: Fake Food Is Trendy Again
node.description: In the world of home décor, maximalism is back — and with it, tchotchkes that were once regarded as kitschy or quaint.

node.title: A Cure for Type 1 Diabetes? For One Man, It Seems to Have Worked.
node.description: A new treatment using stem cells that produce insulin has surprised experts and given them hope for the 1.5 million Americans living with the disease.

node.title: Families Cheer, Some Doctors Worry as Nursing Homes Open Doors Wide to Visitors
node.description: The federal government recently lifted most visitation restrictions at nursing homes. But concerns linger that a full reopening could leave residents vulnerable to another coronavirus surge.

node.title: In Minneapolis Schools, White Families Are Asked to Help Do the Integrating
node.description: In a citywide overhaul, a beloved Black high school was rezoned to include white students from a richer neighborhood. It has been hard for everyone.

node.title: Israel and Iran Broaden Cyberwar to Attack Civilian Targets
node.description: Iranians couldn’t buy gas. Israelis found their intimate dating details posted online. The Iran-Israel shadow war is now hitting ordinary citizens.

node.title: 'Tyrants and Traitors Need to Be Executed,' Said the Army-Vet-Conspiracy-Theorist
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: South Australia tightens border rules less than a week after reopening
node.description: Travellers from low-risk regions like Sydney and Melbourne will have to show evidence of a negative test result from within 72 hours before arriving in SA, and international arrivals will need to quarantine for 14 days.

node.title: WBBL final live: Perth Scorchers face off with Adelaide Strikers in tournament decider
node.description: The WBBL champions will be crowned in Perth, as the Scorchers clash with the Strikers in the final. Follow our live ScoreCentre.

node.title: Mega Millions Numbers for 11/26/21: Did Anyone Win $94 Million?
node.description: A top cash prize option of $67.5 million was on offer on Friday but did anyone take home the big one?

node.title: Western Australia tightens border with South Australia after new COVID cases
node.description: Western Australia will force all arrivals from South Australia to isolate for 14 days under the new rules.

node.title: West Coast prepares for more rain as slips and flooding block SH6
node.description: West Coast Civil Defence has set up an emergency operations centre in Hokitika and will open another in Greymouth this evening.

node.title: Even With Fewer Stars in Beal’s Orbit, the Wizards Find Their Way
node.description: A roster overhaul prioritized depth over big names to surround Bradley Beal in Washington. The new guys — with chips on their shoulders — have come through.

node.title: Wellington: Plan to develop council land near public transport
node.description: The regional council says it has significant land holdings around stations which could be used for housing, retail and public services.

node.title: In a Picture-Postcard New York Town, Racist Incidents Rattle Schools
node.description: When students in Pittsford, a suburb of Rochester, returned to school in the fall, a disturbing video of a white student threatening to kill Black people renewed concerns about racism.

node.title: Afghan Economy Nears Collapse as Pressure Builds to Ease U.S. Sanctions
node.description: Afghanistan’s economy has crashed since the Taliban seized power, plunging the country into one of the world’s worst humanitarian crisis.

node.title: Police charge longest-serving Queensland mayor with assaulting women
node.description: Charges arise from alleged incident during the annual racing event in the tiny north Queensland town in August.

node.title: Tears and prayers at funeral of four children who died in Werribee house fire
node.description: Mourners cried as the tiny coffins were carried overhead of family and friends before being laid to rest.

node.title: Healthcare workers line up for booster shots
node.description: Nurses around the country are relieved to be able to get their booster shots of the vaccine, with appointments starting yesterday.

node.title: 50-50 chance: Doubts growing about Perth hosting Ashes Test match
node.description: Hopes of Perth hosting the fifth and final Ashes Test have faded, with Cricket Australia chief Christina Matthews saying there is a 50:50 chance of the match being hosted in Western Australia.

node.title: Photographs capture extent of floods in north-west NSW
node.description: These images show the impact of floodwaters inundating the saturated plains of the NSW north-west, cutting off towns and submerging crops.

node.title: Broadway's 'greatest lyricist' Stephen Sondheim dead at 91
node.description: One of the most influential composers of the 20th century, Sondheim wrote classics such as West Side Story, Gypsy and Sweeney Todd. Audio

node.title: At ‘Company’ and ‘Assassins,’ Praise for Stephen Sondheim
node.description: “I would ask you to sit back and luxuriate in his extraordinary words and music,” the director John Doyle said before Friday’s performance of the “Assassins” revival.

node.title: Man arrested in South Canterbury over Palmerston North shooting
node.description: A man has been arrested in Twizel, South Canterbury this morning in relation to a shooting in Palmerston North early this month.

node.title: Solomon Islands: Bodies discovered in burnt-out building
node.description: Police in Honiara have confirmed that three bodies have been found in one of the burnt-out buildings in Chinatown.

node.title: Trump Attacks 'Craggy Smug Face' Bob Woodward, 'Lapdog' Robert Costa Over China Claims
node.description: "I never had even a thought of going to war with China, other than the war I was winning, which was on TRADE," said the former president.

node.title: SA opened its borders to COVID-19 this week. Here's what we've learned
node.description: After enjoying months without a single case of local transmission, SA opened up to COVID-19 on Tuesday and the cases have started popping up.

node.title: Iran Forcefully Clamps Down on Protests Against Growing Water Shortages
node.description: The crackdown came after the protests spilled over to at least one other city and a major protest on Friday loomed. Weather experts say 97 percent of the country is dealing with water scarcity issues.

node.title: Man charged with murder, another arrested, over shooting death of woman who answered her door
node.description: A man has been charged with murder, and NSW Police are seeking the extradition of a second man, after Newcastle woman Stacey Klimovitch was shot dead at her front door almost six months ago.

node.title: Pasifika communities reach 'key vaccination milestones'
node.description: Ninety percent of Pacific people in New Zealand have had their first Covid-19 vaccine, while 11 district health boards have reached 80 percent first doses for Māori.

node.title: 'It's Coming': N.Y. Gov. Kathy Hochul Issues Omicron Warning, Declares State of Emergency
node.description: New York became the center of the COVID-19 pandemic when it first began. The Omicron variant threatens to repeat that trend.

node.title: Omicron variant: Vaccine hesitancy, misinformation plagues South Africa
node.description: Experts say vaccination rates need to pick up in Africa, as some citizens take their advice from preachers offering misinformation found on the internet.

node.title: Covid-19: Vaccinations protecting against spread in large households
node.description: The number of big households with Covid-19 cases has doubled in the last month, but overall they make up a falling proportion of the households caught up in the Delta outbreak.

node.title: 3 Bodies Found Amid Violence in Solomon Islands
node.description: The police were trying to determine if the charred remains found in the capital’s Chinatown district were linked to the protests, in which demonstrators set fire to buildings.

node.title: Trump Calls Border 'Bigger Problem' Than Inflation, Says He Could Cure Latter 'Very Quickly'
node.description: "People with murder rap sheets and drug dealers at the highest level, they're all being dumped into the United States," Trump said.

node.title: Matildas seek revenge against world champions USA in Sydney
node.description: The Matildas welcome world champions USA on home soil for the first time in 21 years. Follow our live-blog for all action.

node.title: 'We don't know a lot about it': Health bosses monitoring Omicron outbreak as new travel ban comes into force
node.description: Effective immediately, non-Australian citizens who have been to nine countries, including South Africa, cannot enter Australia.

node.title: Egypt revives ancient road connecting Luxor and Karnak
node.description: A restored road connecting two ancient Egyptian temple complexes in Karnak and Luxor has been unveiled in a lavish ceremony aimed at raising the profile of one of Egypt's top tourist spots.

node.title: LeBron James fined $15,000 for making an "obscene gesture" during game
node.description: The incident comes days after James was suspended for an on-court altercation involving Detroit Pistons center Isaiah Stewart.

node.title: 'Everything that is happening is expected': SA records three new COVID cases
node.description: South Australia records three new cases of COVID-19, as authorities say they are concerned about exposure sites in the state's south-east.

node.title: Thousands take to Melbourne streets in another protest against the vaccine mandate
node.description: Thousands of protesters gather in Melbourne's CBD to oppose the Victorian government's vaccination policies and proposed pandemic laws.

node.title: 'The bulk of this savaging, I deserve': Reporter issues on-air apology for botched Adele interview
node.description: The Australian TV reporter who was widely criticised for flying to the UK to interview singer Adele without listening to her new album issues an on-air apology, admitting he made a "terrible mistake".

node.title: NSW changes travel advice for southern Africa in response to new COVID variant
node.description: Travellers arriving in NSW from southern Africa are now required to get tested for COVID-19 and isolate as health officials move to stop the spread of the new Omicron variant.

node.title: Covid-19: US, Europe ban Africa flights after Omicron variant discovery
node.description: The United States has joined the European Union in imposing an emergency flight ban on countries in southern Africa after the discovery of the new Covid-19 variant dubbed Omicron.

node.title: West Coast Civil Defence prepares ahead of forecast heavy rain
node.description: West Coast Civil Defence has set up an emergency operations centre in Hokitika as a precaution, with heavy rain forecast for the region this weekend.

node.title: Unionized workers fight for better pay in post-pandemic economy
node.description: "Workers definitely have more labor market leverage because employers need to hire," said one expert.

node.title: The Essential Musical Dramatist Who Taught Us to Hear
node.description: With a childlike sense of discovery, Stephen Sondheim found the language to convey the beauty in harsh complexity.

node.title: Giving Thanks in Australia
node.description: It’s an odd affair outside America, but maybe the holiday will inspire more of us to pause and appreciate the gifts we’ve been given.

node.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Calls for GOP Leaders to Oust 'Traitors' Katko, Kinzinger and Cheney
node.description: "This type of sadistic behavior can NOT be tolerated," Greene tweeted. "They must be held accountable for their reprehensible actions."

node.title: Doctors were ready to let Tristan 'cark it' after a terrible accident. He just graduated from high school
node.description: A Queensland mother says she never imagined what her son would achieve when she ignored doctors' advice to turn off his life support four years ago.

node.title: First fatalities of Solomon Islands unrest discovered in burnt-out Chinatown store
node.description: Charred bodies are discovered in a building in the capital Honiara as more Australians make their way to the Pacific nation to restore order and protect critical infrastructure.

node.title: NT records one new local case of COVID, Katherine to move from lockdown to lockout from midday
node.description: Katherine will move from out of lockdown and into a lockout from 12pm today, after only one new local case of COVID-19 was recorded in the NT.

node.title: Eroad makes net loss of $2.9m for six months to September
node.description: Transport software company Eroad has slipped to a half year loss as Covid-19 affected sales, and expenses rose as it pressed on with market and product development ahead of its takeover of a rival…

node.title: MidCentral DHB 'as well-prepared as we can be' for Covid-19 cases
node.description: Plans are in place and now health officials in the MidCentral region are waiting to see if their preparation will be the bedrock to surviving a summer period of learning to live with Covid-19.

node.title: Countdown distribution workers win pay rise after striking
node.description: Countdown supermarket distribution centre workers have won a pay rise after a three-day strike this week.

node.title: Documents reveal scale of change needed to cut emissions
node.description: The massive scale of the nationwide changes needed quickly to cut climate gas emissions is laid bare in newly-released government documents.

node.title: A College Football Crash Course for Thanksgiving
node.description: This weekend’s rivalries could lead to some familial bickering at the dinner table. But there are national title implications, too.

node.title: Days Before Dying, Stephen Sondheim Reflects: ‘I’ve Been Lucky’
node.description: In an interview on Sunday, the revered composer and lyricist, 91, contentedly discussed his shows running on Broadway and off, as well as a new movie about to be released.

node.title: In the Midst of the Mud and Destruction, British Columbians Come Together
node.description: A tour of the flood-ravaged parts of the province finds communities supporting each other following disaster.

node.title: New Jersey Cop Who Killed Pedestrian, Took Body Home, Was Turned In By Father: Prosecutor
node.description: The cop's lawyer said the pedestrian was wearing a werewolf costume and walking against the flow of highway traffic when the collision occurred.

node.title: Only nine farms remain in local hands in Tasmania's dairy country but a farmer group wants to turn the tables
node.description: In a region with one of the highest levels of corporate and foreign-owned farmland in Australia, a farmer investment group has sprung up in Tasmania's north-west to keep local farmers on the land.

node.title: Man escapes quarantine and heads to Darwin's party strip before being located by police
node.description: A man who allegedly snuck out of the Howard Springs quarantine facility is found by police almost six hours later at a licensed venue in the Darwin CBD.

node.title: One new COVID case detected in Queensland as state tracks a week ahead for vaccination target
node.description: Queensland records one new case of coronavirus as the state tracks towards hitting the 80 per cent double vaccination milestone on December 10.

node.title: Bridge collapses under floodwater, other drivers pulled to safety
node.description: Major flooding in New South Wales has seen a bridge collapse, and elsewhere, people pulled to safety after their cars were swept from roads.

node.title: NZ has no plans to evacuate citizens in Solomon Islands
node.description: After several days of rioting, 43 New Zealanders in the islands are warned to stay away from demonstrations.

node.title: Lauren Boebert's Apology to Omar Makes No Mention of 'Chest Feed' Remark Aimed at Buttigieg
node.description: Critics of Boebert's "chest feed" remark called it homophobic and insulting to the estimated 228,000 same-sex parents raising children in the United States.

node.title: 'Counterproductive': Gottlieb Pans U.S. Travel Ban on African Countries Over Omicron Variant
node.description: Former FDA commissioner Scott Gottlieb said that "harsh travel restrictions" will affect efforts to control the spread of the new variant.

node.title: Birdwatcher Clifford Sunfly has just joined a very exclusive club
node.description: Considered to be one of the world's most mysterious birds, the elusive night parrot has been seen by fewer than 20 people who are still alive today.

node.title: Biden wants COVID vaccine IP protections waived amid concern over Omicron variant
node.description: US President Joe Biden calls on nations meeting at the World Trade Organization next week to agree to waive intellectual property protections for COVID-19 vaccines as a new coronavirus variant is detected.

node.title: A Times correspondent reports from a plane held on the tarmac in Amsterdam.
node.description: By Stephanie Nolen

node.title: NSW teachers to strike over pay and staff shortages
node.description: Teachers in public schools across New South Wales vote unanimously to go on strike next month.

node.title: Northeast expected to see first significant snowfall
node.description: Some areas could see see more than 8 inches of snow this weekend.

node.title: New Virus Variant Stokes Concern but Vaccines May Still Work
node.description: The Omicron variant carries worrisome mutations that may let it evade antibodies, scientists said. But it will take more research to know how it fares against vaccinated people.

node.title: Seeking Backers for New Fund, Jared Kushner Turns to Middle East
node.description: Former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law is trying to raise capital for his investment firm and is turning to a region that he dealt with extensively while in the White House.

node.title: Britain, China and Germany all win the same skeleton World Cup race
node.description: Geng Wengiang of China, Matt Weston of Britain and Christopher Grotheer of Germany finish their gold medal runs at the skeleton World Cup with the same times, completing a historic three-way tie.

node.title: Stephen Sondheim dies aged 91
node.description: US musical theatre giant Stephen Sondheim, the composer and lyricist behind Broadway hits such as West Side Story, Into the Woods and Sweeney Todd, dies aged 91.

node.title: Musical theater legend Stephen Sondheim dies at 91
node.description: The composer and lyricist earned a Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2015.

node.title: President Biden Warns New Omicron COVID Variant 'Spreads Rapidly,' Urges Booster Shots
node.description: "Get your booster shot now, so you can have this additional protection during the holiday season," Biden urged fully vaccinated Americans on Friday.

node.title: Dizzy Bility is deaf and blind — but that hasn't stopped her from achieving drag queen stardom
node.description: Drag queen Dizzy Bility was born with a condition that causes worsening vision and hearing loss, but has been welcomed by Sydney's drag community. She hopes her experiences are helping change societal perceptions of people with a disability.

node.title: The warnings were ominous, but just how did Mark McGowan use his party's total control of WA's parliament?
node.description: When Labor took full control of the WA Parliament in a historic election this year, the warnings from the opposition were ominous, so how has the first year of an extraordinary parliament awash with Labor MPs played out?

node.title: Vets who treated sick dogs fear there's more toxic meat in freezers
node.description: In June, a Victorian veterinarian clinic started seeing dogs with a mystery illness. A week later they were inundated with sick animals.

node.title: 'Not knowing is really the worst': Backpacker's family calls for review of missing person's case
node.description: The family of missing Belgian backpacker Theo Hayez say they hope an upcoming coronial inquest will investigate a number of scenarios around his disappearance from Byron Bay.

node.title: Victoria records 1,252 new local COVID-19 cases and five deaths
node.description: There are now 11,257 active cases of the virus in Victoria, and 499 people have died during the state's current Delta outbreak.

node.title: What happens when a town runs out of rentals and prices go through the roof?
node.description: Regional rental prices are continuing to boom, pricing some of Victoria's more vulnerable residents out of the market. So what can be done to ensure no-one is left behind?

node.title: Scientists scramble to unpick secrets of new Omicron COVID variant as WHO calls for calm
node.description: The new Omicron coronavirus strain causes international borders to slam shut and global financial markets to plunge, amid fears about how current vaccines will fare against it.

node.title: Turkey: Police fire tear gas at women's rights march
node.description: Riot police in Turkey have fired tear gas at protesters calling for an end to violence against women.

node.title: Italy, France to deepen ties as Merkel's exit tests European diplomacy
node.description: The leaders of Italy and France will sign a treaty on Friday to strengthen bilateral ties at a time when European diplomacy is being tested by the departure of German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

node.title: 'What do we do?' - Store owners frustrated over crime wave
node.description: Auckland business owners who say crime is on the rise in the inner city are crying out for help. Audio

node.title: This week on "Sunday Morning" (November 28)
node.description: A look at the features for this week's broadcast of the #1 Sunday morning news program

node.title: After detecting the Omnicron variant, South Africa feels ‘punished’ by global travel bans.
node.description: Hours after South African scientists announced the existence of a troublesome new variant, Britain banned travelers from southern Africa. The United States and other nations quickly followed suit.

node.title: Company with licence to run iconic Tasmanian walk bills taxpayers for marketing costs
node.description: The commercial company running Tasmania's Three Capes Track has been paid hundreds of thousands of dollars by the state government for marketing costs.

node.title: Despite calls from Aboriginal groups to delay reopening NT's borders, government will push ahead with plan
node.description: The Northern Territory Health Minister says the government is "not going to fall over at the final hurdle" by delaying its plan to reopen borders by December 20 but Aboriginal health groups call for quarantine requirements to be maintained until remote communities reach a much higher rate of vaccination coverage.
